subject_question.title: Subject Questions
subject_question.content:
A Subject Question asks about the doer or performer of an action. The question word (like Who, What, or Which) is the subject of the sentence.

The key rule is that we do not use auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The sentence structure is like a normal statement.

Structure:

Question Word (Subject) + Main Verb + (Object)?

Examples:

  • Who implemented this feature?
  • What causes this conflict?
  • Which team has the latest code?

object_question.title: Object Questions
object_question.content:
An Object Question asks about the receiver of an action. The subject is known, and the question word asks about the object.

The key rule is that we must use auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The structure requires inversion.

Structure:

Question Word (Object) + Auxiliary Verb + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • What module did the team modify?
  • Who did you ask?
  • Which report does this issue mention?

negative_questions.title: Negative Questions
negative_questions.content:
Negative questions are used to confirm something you think is true, or to express surprise. They are very common in conversation.

They are usually formed with a contracted auxiliary verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Shouldn't, Didn't) at the beginning.

Structure:

Negative Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • Don't you think this is too complex?
  • Shouldn't this feature be in production?
  • Didn't we fix this issue already?

present_perfect.title: Present Perfect
present_perfect.content:
The Present Perfect connects the past with the present. It's used for actions that happened at an unspecified time in the past or actions that started in the past and continue to the present.

It focuses on the result or relevance of the action now, not when it happened.

Structure:

Subject + have/has + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I have finished my part of the project. (The result is important now).
  • She has worked here for five years. (She still works here).
  • Have you seen the latest design mockups?

present_perfect_continuous.title: Present Perfect Continuous
present_perfect_continuous.content:
The Present Perfect Continuous is used for an action that started in the past and is still in progress now, or has very recently stopped.

It emphasizes the duration of the action.

Structure:

Subject + have/has been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I have been trying to solve this bug all day.
  • The team has been developing this feature since last month.
  • He looks tired because he has been working late.

past_perfect.title: Past Perfect
past_perfect.content:
The Past Perfect is used to talk about an action that happened before another action in the past. It clarifies the sequence of events.

Think of it as the 'past of the past'.

Structure:

Subject + had + Past Participle

Examples:

  • The system crashed after we had deployed the changes.
  • He had already left when I arrived.
  • By the time they responded, I had found a solution.

first_conditional.title: First Conditional
first_conditional.content:
The First Conditional is used to talk about real and possible future situations. It describes a likely result if a certain condition is met.

Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... will + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If we finish early, we will deploy the update.
  • If the server goes down, I will call you immediately.
  • You will miss the deadline if you don't start now.

second_conditional.title: Second Conditional
second_conditional.content:
The Second Conditional is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. It describes an imaginary result for an unreal condition.

Structure:

If + Past Simple, ... would + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If I had more time, I would refactor this module.
  • If we had the budget, we would hire another developer.
  • What would you do if you were the project manager?

third_conditional.title: Third Conditional
third_conditional.content:
The Third Conditional is used to talk about hypothetical situations in the past. It describes an imaginary result for a past condition that did not happen. It's often used to express regret.

Structure:

If + Past Perfect, ... would have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • If I had known about the bug, I would have fixed it.
  • If we had tested it better, the system would not have crashed.
  • They would have finished on time if the requirements hadn't changed.

modal_perfects.title: Modal Perfects (should have, could have)
modal_perfects.content:
Modal Perfects (Modal + have + Past Participle) are used to speculate about or judge past actions. They are a common way to express opinions about what happened.

  • Should have: Expresses regret or criticism about a past action that didn't happen.
  • Could have: Expresses a past possibility that was not taken.
  • Would have: Used in the Third Conditional (see separate rule).

Examples:

  • I should have committed my code before leaving. (Regret)
  • You could have asked for help instead of struggling. (Untaken possibility)
  • He must have forgotten about the meeting. (Logical deduction about the past)

passive_voice.title: The Passive Voice
passive_voice.content:
The Passive Voice is used when the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, not on the person who performs it (the agent).

It is very common in technical and formal writing.

Structure:

Object + be (conjugated) + Past Participle (+ by Agent)

Examples:

  • The new feature was implemented last week. (Focus is on the feature).
  • The server is being restarted now.
  • This report must be finished by tomorrow. (The agent is not important).

gerunds_and_infinitives.title: Gerunds (-ing) vs. Infinitives (to + verb)
gerunds_and_infinitives.content:
Whether you use a gerund or an infinitive after a verb depends on the main verb.

  • Gerunds (-ing) are used after certain verbs like 'enjoy', 'avoid', 'finish', 'consider', and 'suggest'. They function like nouns.
  • Infinitives (to + verb) are used after verbs like 'want', 'need', 'decide', 'plan', and 'promise'.

Some verbs, like 'like', 'love', and 'start', can be followed by either with little change in meaning.

Examples:

  • We should avoid deploying on a Friday.
  • I decided to refactor the entire class.
  • She suggested using a different library.

gerunds_after_prepositions.title: Gerunds after Prepositions
gerunds_after_prepositions.content:
This is a very consistent rule in English: if a verb follows a preposition (in, on, at, for, about, without, etc.), the verb must be in its gerund (-ing) form.

This rule also applies to phrasal verbs that end in a preposition, like 'look forward to'.

Structure:

... Preposition + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • Thank you for helping me with the setup.
  • We can't move forward without approving the budget.
  • I'm looking forward to seeing the final product.

used_to_vs_be_used_to.title: Used to vs. Be used to
used_to_vs_be_used_to.content:
These two expressions look similar but have completely different meanings and structures.

  • used to + base verb: Refers to a past habit or state that is no longer true. It means 'solía'.
  • be used to + gerund (-ing): Refers to being accustomed to or familiar with something. It means 'estar acostumbrado a'.

Examples:

  • I used to write code in Java. (I don't anymore).
  • I am used to writing code in Dart. (I am accustomed to it now).
  • He isn't used to working in such a large team.

phrasal_verbs.title: Phrasal Verbs
phrasal_verbs.content:
A Phrasal Verb is a combination of a standard verb (like 'get', 'take', 'come') and one or two particles (usually a preposition or adverb like 'up', 'on', 'away').

The meaning of the combination is often very different from the meaning of the individual words. They are extremely common in informal English.

Examples:

  • Take care of: to deal with or handle something.
  • Come up with: to think of an idea or plan.
  • Run into: to encounter or meet someone/something by chance.

false_friends.title: False Friends
false_friends.content:
False Friends (or 'false cognates') are words in two different languages that look or sound similar, but have different meanings.

They are a common source of mistakes for learners. It is important to learn them to avoid misunderstandings.

Examples:

  • Assist (English) vs. Asistir (Spanish): 'Assist' means to help, while 'asistir' means to attend.
  • Library (English) vs. Librería (Spanish): 'Library' is a place to borrow books (biblioteca), while 'librería' is a bookstore.
  • Actually (English) vs. Actualmente (Spanish): 'Actually' means 'in fact' or 'really', while 'actualmente' means 'currently'.

make_vs_do.title: Make vs. Do
make_vs_do.content:
Do and Make are two verbs that are often confused. The general rule is:

  • Use Do for actions, obligations, and repetitive tasks. It focuses on the process of acting. (e.g., do homework, do a job, do research).
  • Use Make for creating, constructing, or producing something new that wasn't there before. It focuses on the result. (e.g., make a mistake, make a decision, make a sound).

When in doubt, it's often best to learn them as fixed expressions.

modal_verbs_future.title: Modal Verbs: Future Equivalents
modal_verbs_future.content:
Modal verbs like can, must, and may do not have future tense forms on their own. You cannot say 'will can' or 'will must'.

To express these ideas in the future, we use their equivalent phrasal forms.

Common Equivalents:

  • Future of can (ability) → will be able to.
  • Future of must (obligation) → will have to.
  • Future of may (permission) → will be allowed to.

Example:

~I will can join the meeting.~ (Incorrect)
I will be able to join the meeting. (Correct)

possessive_nouns.title: Possessive Nouns ('s)
possessive_nouns.content:
To show that something belongs to a noun, we usually add an apostrophe + s ('s). This is a very common and natural way to express possession in English.

This structure is often more idiomatic than using 'of the'.

Examples:

  • 'the meeting of tomorrow' → 'tomorrow's meeting'
  • 'the report of the issue' → 'the issue's report'
  • 'the car of my friend' → 'my friend's car'

For plural nouns that already end in -s, we just add an apostrophe: 'the developers' computers'.

prepositions_of_time.title: Prepositions of Time: In, On, At
prepositions_of_time.content:
Choosing the correct preposition for time expressions follows some general rules:

  • IN is used for longer, non-specific periods like months, years, seasons, and decades.
    Example: in August, in 2025, in the summer.
  • ON is used for specific days and dates.
    Example: on Friday, on my birthday, on July 4th.
  • AT is used for specific times of the day.
    Example: at 3:00 PM, at noon, at midnight.

prepositions_of_place.title: Prepositions of Place: In, On, At
prepositions_of_place.content:
These prepositions can also refer to location. The general rules are:

  • IN is used for an enclosed space or a large area (countries, cities).
    Example: The file is in the folder. / He works in London.
  • ON is used for a surface.
    Example: The laptop is on the desk. / The logo is on the webpage.
  • AT is used for a specific point or location.
    Example: Let's meet at the main entrance. / He is at his desk.

adjective_vs_adverb.title: Adjective vs. Adverb
adjective_vs_adverb.content:
An adjective describes a noun (a person, place, or thing). A common example is good.

An adverb describes a verb (an action), an adjective, or another adverb. A common example is well.

Examples:

  • He is a good developer. ('good' describes the noun 'developer')
  • He develops well. ('well' describes the verb 'develops')

A frequent mistake is using 'good' to describe a verb: ~I understood it good.~ → I understood it well.

still_vs_yet.title: Still vs. Yet
still_vs_yet.content:
Both words can relate to time, but they are used in different types of sentences.

  • Still is used for an action that continues to the present, often longer than expected. It is almost always used in affirmative (positive) sentences.
    Example: We are still working on the issue.
  • Yet is used for something that is expected but has not happened. It is almost always used in negative sentences and questions.
    Example: We haven't fixed it yet. / Have you fixed it yet?

so_vs_such.title: So vs. Such
so_vs_such.content:
Both 'so' and 'such' are used for emphasis, but they have different grammatical structures.

  • So is followed by an adjective or adverb.
    Structure: so + adjective/adverb
  • Such is followed by a noun or an adjective + noun.
    Structure: such + (a/an) + (adjective) + noun

Examples:

  • The process was so complicated.
  • It was such a complicated process.
  • He codes so quickly.

ago_vs_for.title: Ago vs. For
ago_vs_for.content:
These words are used with time expressions but have different functions.

  • Ago is used with the Past Simple to indicate a finished action at a specific time before now. It always goes at the end of the phrase.
    Example: I started this job three years ago.
  • For is used with the Present Perfect to describe the duration of an action that continues to the present.
    Example: I have worked here for three years.

comparatives_and_superlatives.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
comparatives_and_superlatives.content:
We use comparatives and superlatives to compare things.

  • Comparatives compare two things. For short adjectives, add '-er' (e.g., faster). For long adjectives, use 'more' (e.g., more efficient).
  • Superlatives compare three or more things. For short adjectives, add '-est' (e.g., fastest). For long adjectives, use 'the most' (e.g., the most efficient).

Examples:

  • This API is faster than the old one.
  • This is the most difficult task in the project.
  • Python is easier to learn than C++.

adjective_order.title: Adjective Order
adjective_order.content:
When using multiple adjectives to describe a noun, they usually follow a specific order. A common guide is OSASCOMP.

Opinion, Size, Age, Shape, Color, Origin, Material, Purpose.

You rarely use more than two or three at once, but the order remains important for sounding natural.

Examples:

  • A big old server. (Size, Age)
  • An efficient new American system. (Opinion, Age, Origin)
  • A small plastic component. (Size, Material)

countable_vs_uncountable.title: Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns
countable_vs_uncountable.content:
The distinction between countable and uncountable nouns is important for using articles and quantifiers correctly.

  • Countable Nouns can be counted and have a plural form (e.g., one bug, two bugs). Use 'many', 'a few'.
  • Uncountable Nouns cannot be counted and do not have a plural form (e.g., information, software, advice, progress). Use 'much', 'a little'.

Examples:

  • How many tickets are open?
  • How much progress have we made?
  • We need a little information before we start.

articles_a_an_the.title: Articles: A/An vs. The
articles_a_an_the.content:
Articles specify the definiteness of a noun.

  • A/An (Indefinite Article) is used for a general, non-specific noun. 'A' is used before consonant sounds, 'An' before vowel sounds.
    Example: We need a solution. (Any solution, not a specific one).
  • The (Definite Article) is used for a specific noun that both the speaker and listener know.
    Example: We need the solution we discussed yesterday. (A specific one).

zero_article.title: Zero Article (No Article)
zero_article.content:
Sometimes, no article is needed before a noun. This is called the 'zero article'.

It is typically used when speaking about things in general, with plural or uncountable nouns.

Examples:

  • Software development is a complex field. (General concept, uncountable).
  • Bugs are inevitable in any project. (General concept, plural).
  • I like music. (General, uncountable).

Compare: 'Bugs are a problem' (general) vs. 'The bugs in this module are a problem' (specific).

too_vs_enough.title: Too vs. Enough
too_vs_enough.content:
'Too' and 'enough' are used to talk about quantity, but they have opposite meanings.

  • Too indicates an excess of something (more than needed). It has a negative connotation.
    Structure: too + adjective/adverb.
  • Enough indicates a sufficient amount (the right quantity).
    Structure: adjective/adverb + enough OR enough + noun.

Examples:

  • This task is too difficult to finish today.
  • This server is not powerful enough.
  • We don't have enough time to test everything.

conjunctions_of_contrast.title: Connectors of Contrast
conjunctions_of_contrast.content:
These words connect two contrasting ideas. The key difference is their grammatical structure.

  • Although / Even though are followed by a clause (subject + verb).
    Example: Although the code works, it is not efficient.
  • Despite / In spite of are followed by a noun or a gerund (-ing).
    Example: Despite the problems, we launched on time.
  • However connects two separate sentences.
    Example: The plan is good. However, we lack the resources.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Clauses (who, which, that)
relative_clauses.content:
A Relative Clause adds extra information about a noun. It is introduced by a relative pronoun.

  • Who is used for people.
  • Which is used for things.
  • That can be used for both people and things (usually in defining clauses).

Examples:

  • The developer who wrote this code is on vacation.
  • This is the bug which is blocking the release.
  • She is the expert that we need to consult.

question_tags.title: Question Tags
question_tags.content:
A Question Tag is a short question at the end of a statement, used to ask for confirmation. They are very common in spoken English.

The rule is: a positive statement has a negative tag, and a negative statement has a positive tag. The tag uses the same auxiliary verb as the statement.

Examples:

  • The deployment was successful, wasn't it?
  • You have tested this feature, haven't you?
  • He can't access the server, can he?

get_plus_adjective.title: Get + Adjective
get_plus_adjective.content:
The verb get is often used with an adjective to express a change of state. It is a dynamic alternative to 'become' or 'turn'.

This structure is very common in everyday English.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Adjective

Examples:

  • I am getting tired of these repetitive tasks.
  • The situation got complicated very quickly.
  • Don't get angry, it's just a minor issue.

had_better.title: Had Better
had_better.content:
Had better is a modal expression used to give strong advice or a warning. It implies that there will be negative consequences if the advice is not followed.

Despite using 'had', it refers to the present or immediate future, not the past.

Structure:

Subject + 'd better + Base Verb

Examples:

  • You'd better submit that report before the deadline.
  • We'd better not break the build again.
  • He'd better call the client back immediately.

be_supposed_to.title: Be Supposed To
be_supposed_to.content:
The expression be supposed to is used to talk about what is expected, arranged, or intended to happen. It often implies that the reality is different from the expectation.

Structure:

Subject + be (conjugated) + supposed to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • This API key is supposed to give us admin access. (But it doesn't).
  • I was supposed to finish this yesterday. (But I didn't).
  • The meeting is supposed to start at 10 AM.

causative_verbs.title: Causative Verbs (let, make, have, get)
causative_verbs.content:
Causative Verbs express an action that one person causes another person to do. The structure varies depending on the verb.

  • let someone do something (permit)
  • make someone do something (force/compel)
  • have someone do something (give responsibility)
  • get someone to do something (persuade)

Examples:

  • The manager let me leave early.
  • He made me rewrite the entire document.
  • I'll have my assistant send you the details.
  • I can't get this code to work.

wish_if_only.title: Wish / If Only
wish_if_only.content:
We use wish and if only to express regrets about the past or desires for the present/future to be different. The verb tense that follows is 'shifted back' one step into the past.

  • For present wishes: wish + past simple.
  • For past regrets: wish + past perfect.

Examples:

  • I wish I had more time to complete this. (Present wish).
  • He wishes he knew the answer. (Present wish).
  • I wish I had saved my work more often. (Past regret).

would_rather.title: Would Rather
would_rather.content:
Would rather is used to express a preference for one thing over another in a specific situation. It is followed by a base verb.

When comparing two actions, use the structure 'would rather do A than do B'.

Structure:

Subject + 'd rather + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I'd rather finish this today than leave it for tomorrow.
  • She'd rather work from home.
  • Would you rather have the meeting now or later?

whatever_wherever_whenever.title: Words ending in -ever
whatever_wherever_whenever.content:
Words like whatever, wherever, whenever, whoever are used to express the idea of 'any' or 'it doesn't matter which/where/when/who'.

  • Whatever: Anything at all.
  • Wherever: Any place at all.
  • Whenever: Any time at all.
  • However: In any way at all.

Examples:

  • Do whatever it takes to fix the problem.
  • You can deploy the code whenever you're ready.
  • We need to follow the style guide, however difficult it may seem.

as_long_as_provided_that.title: As long as / Provided that
as_long_as_provided_that.content:
These phrases are used to express a condition. They are alternatives to 'if', often sounding slightly more formal. They mean 'on the condition that'.

Both are followed by a clause in the present tense when referring to the future.

Examples:

  • You can take the lead as long as you follow the project plan.
  • We can approve the change provided that it passes all the tests.
  • The feature will be included as long as we have enough time.

either_or_neither_nor.title: Either/Or and Neither/Nor
either_or_neither_nor.content:
These correlative conjunctions are used to connect two choices.

  • Either ... or ... is used to present a choice between two positive options.
  • Neither ... nor ... is used to connect two negative statements, meaning 'not the first one and not the second one'.

When 'neither/nor' is used, the verb is positive because the negation is already included.

Examples:

  • We can use either REST or GraphQL for this service.
  • Neither the developer nor the manager was available.
  • The bug is neither in the front-end nor in the back-end.

reported_speech_statements.title: Reported Speech (Statements)
reported_speech_statements.content:
Reported Speech (or Indirect Speech) is used to report what someone else said, without using their exact words. The verb tense usually 'shifts back' one step into the past.

  • Present Simple → Past Simple
  • Present Continuous → Past Continuous
  • Past Simple → Past Perfect

Examples:

  • Direct: 'The API is ready.' → Reported: He said the API was ready.
  • Direct: 'I am working on it.' → Reported: She said she was working on it.
  • Direct: 'We finished yesterday.' → Reported: They said they had finished the day before.

reported_speech_questions.title: Reported Speech (Questions)
reported_speech_questions.content:
When reporting questions, the sentence structure changes from a question (with inversion) to a statement. We also use reporting verbs like 'asked'.

  • For Yes/No questions, use 'if' or 'whether'.
  • For Wh- questions, use the same question word.

Do not use auxiliaries like 'do' or 'did'.

Examples:

  • Direct: 'Are you finished?' → Reported: He asked if I was finished.
  • Direct: 'Where is the file?' → Reported: She asked where the file was.
  • Direct: 'What did you change?' → Reported: They asked what I had changed.

infinitive_of_purpose.title: Infinitive of Purpose
infinitive_of_purpose.content:
To explain the purpose or reason for an action, we use the infinitive with 'to'. This is a very common and concise structure.

It answers the question 'Why?'. It is a much more natural alternative than using 'for + gerund'.

Structure:

... Action + to + Base Verb ...

Examples:

  • I called a meeting to discuss the new requirements.
  • He wrote a script to automate the deployment process.
  • We need to run more tests to ensure quality.

singular_they.title: Singular 'They'
singular_they.content:
In modern English, it is very common and grammatically correct to use 'they' as a singular, gender-neutral pronoun.

It is used when a person's gender is unknown, irrelevant, or non-binary.

Examples:

  • If a developer has a question, they should ask their team lead.
  • Someone left their laptop in the meeting room.
  • The new manager is great; I really like them.

prepositions_for_vs_of.title: Prepositions: For vs. Of
prepositions_for_vs_of.content:
While both can be translated as 'de' in Spanish, their use in English is distinct.

  • Of is generally used to show possession, belonging, or parts of a whole.
    Example: The corner of the room. / The name of the file.
  • For is generally used to show purpose, reason, or a beneficiary.
    Example: A key for the door. / A fix for this issue.

'The fix of this issue' sounds unnatural because the fix's purpose is to solve the issue. Therefore, 'the fix for this issue' is the correct and idiomatic choice.

question_formation_auxiliaries.title: Question Formation (with Auxiliaries)
question_formation_auxiliaries.content:
In English, most questions in the simple present and simple past require an auxiliary verb before the subject. This is called inversion.

Structure:

(Wh- Word) + Auxiliary Verb + Subject + Main Verb (base form)?

Examples:

  • What do you think?
  • Why did the build fail?

Remember, the main verb always returns to its base form (e.g., 'fail', not 'failed') when an auxiliary is present.

subject_verb_agreement_questions.title: Subject-Verb Agreement in Questions
subject_verb_agreement_questions.content:
When forming questions with 'do' and 'does', the verb must agree with the subject.

Structure:

Do/Does + Subject + Main Verb (base form)?

Examples:

  • Do these logs contain the data? ('logs' is plural)
  • Does this change apply to QA? ('change' is singular)

A common mistake is to look at the wrong noun. In 'the latest report of bugs', the subject is 'report' (singular), not 'bugs' (plural). So, the correct question is: 'Does the latest report...'
